item.title: Heap Questions
item.description:
Can Heaps have one node?

I ask this question because of questions like: "T or F: the largest value in a min heap can be found at the root"

Technically this could be true if the heap is one node. also,

"T or F: A binary tree with one node must be a heap"

This is true if it can be one node right?
item.content:encoded:
Can Heaps have one node?

I ask this question because of questions like: "T or F: the largest value in a min heap can be found at the root"

Technically this could be true if the heap is one node. also,

"T or F: A binary tree with one node must be a heap"

This is true if it can be one node right?

item.title: #186 - binary tree with 10 leaves
item.description:
Suppose a binary tree has 10 leaves. How many nodes in the tree must have 2 children? 

I'm trying to draw out a variety of binary trees with 10 leaves, but I was wondering if there was a mathematical approach to solving this problem. Is there? Or is there an aspect of the definition of binary trees that would answer this question?
item.content:encoded:
Suppose a binary tree has 10 leaves. How many nodes in the tree must have 2 children? 

I'm trying to draw out a variety of binary trees with 10 leaves, but I was wondering if there was a mathematical approach to solving this problem. Is there? Or is there an aspect of the definition of binary trees that would answer this question?

item.title: Recursive Functions
item.description:
In the directions for "Tracing recursive functions", it states:

"When asked about the number of recursive calls, do not include the original call".

Just to be clear- does that mean when an if statement is looped through a total of 5 times, then 4 are considered recursive calls?
item.content:encoded:
In the directions for "Tracing recursive functions", it states:

"When asked about the number of recursive calls, do not include the original call".

Just to be clear- does that mean when an if statement is looped through a total of 5 times, then 4 are considered recursive calls?

item.title: Pre-Req Test Last Call
item.description:
So as we all await the inevitable Pre-req test Monday, I thought it best we have a thread to showcase concepts so that we can cover bases we may have missed or perhaps still struggle with.

For instance to start, time complexity from least to greatest goes constant, log n, linear, n log n, quadratic, cubic, exponential, n!
item.content:encoded:
So as we all await the inevitable Pre-req test Monday, I thought it best we have a thread to showcase concepts so that we can cover bases we may have missed or perhaps still struggle with.

For instance to start, time complexity from least to greatest goes constant, log n, linear, n log n, quadratic, cubic, exponential, n!

item.description:

Figured it wouldn't hurt to ask.

Roll Tide.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Merging two heaps of size n and m, m < n takes how much time?
item.description:
A. theta(n * m)
B. theta(n log m)
C. theta(log n + log m)
D. theta(n + m)
E. theta(log n * log m)
F. theta(m log n)

I'm getting different answers depending on what sources I use. Most of them seem to say D (theta n+m) because you can simply make a new array out of the two arrays rather than merging each element individually. However building a heap has omicron n log n complexity. I'm very confused.
item.content:encoded:
A. theta(n * m)
B. theta(n log m)
C. theta(log n + log m)
D. theta(n + m)
E. theta(log n * log m)
F. theta(m log n)

I'm getting different answers depending on what sources I use. Most of them seem to say D (theta n+m) because you can simply make a new array out of the two arrays rather than merging each element individually. However building a heap has omicron n log n complexity. I'm very confused.

item.title: Collabrative Answer Sheet
item.description:
I've created a google sheet where we will compile all of the questions for the prereq test.

Access the sheet here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1...sp=sharing

To add your answers, please put it in a new column. Do not overwrite answers that someone has previously put, even if you think they are wrong. If you'd like, you can put an explanation for your answer in as well. 

Even if you don't think you know any of the answers, we also need help copying the 200+ questions into the sheet. Thank you in advance!
item.content:encoded:
I've created a google sheet where we will compile all of the questions for the prereq test.

Access the sheet here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1...sp=sharing

To add your answers, please put it in a new column. Do not overwrite answers that someone has previously put, even if you think they are wrong. If you'd like, you can put an explanation for your answer in as well. 

Even if you don't think you know any of the answers, we also need help copying the 200+ questions into the sheet. Thank you in advance!

item.title: question 92 ???
item.description:
is this question supposed to say faster or slower than g 
where  true is 


92. If f = O(g), then it is possible that algorithm f can run true than g, for some problem sizes.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: n^0.9*log(n) v.s. n [Visualized]
item.description:
The use of a graphing calculator can really help understand the growth rate of algorithms, along with proving that the constants do not matter. Personally, I use https://www.desmos.com/calculator

But when doing this, you must consider going to infinity. Plot f(x) = x on the website provided, than plot g(x) = x^0.9 * log(x). At first glimpse, and with zooming out a little, you'll believe that g(x) has a quicker growth rate. But if you zoom WAY out, you'll notice when x = 1 * 10^10, the function f(x) overcomes the growth rate of g(x).
item.content:encoded:
The use of a graphing calculator can really help understand the growth rate of algorithms, along with proving that the constants do not matter. Personally, I use https://www.desmos.com/calculator

But when doing this, you must consider going to infinity. Plot f(x) = x on the website provided, than plot g(x) = x^0.9 * log(x). At first glimpse, and with zooming out a little, you'll believe that g(x) has a quicker growth rate. But if you zoom WAY out, you'll notice when x = 1 * 10^10, the function f(x) overcomes the growth rate of g(x).
